item.title: Trump Investigations Face a Dilemma Before the Midterm Elections
item.description: Justice Department officials are debating how an unwritten rule should affect the criminal investigations into Jan. 6 and the former president’s handling of sensitive documents.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Despite its name, the Justice Department’s 60-day rule is a general principle rather than a written law or regulation.

item.title: Republicans Seek Path for Constitutional Convention
item.description: A new book by a former Democratic senator warns of the risks of allowing states to call for a convention. Some in the G.O.P. see it as the only way to rein in the federal government.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: Conservative Republicans in Congress are seeking to clear a path for a constitutional convention.

item.title: Europe’s Leaders Vow Economic Relief, Fearing Unrest
item.description: Germany, Sweden and the Czech Republic announced measures to populations feeling the bite of rising inflation and energy costs tied to war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:credit: Martin Divisek/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A protest in Prague on Saturday against the Czech government and its response to the energy crisis.

item.title: As Russia Chokes Europe’s Gas, France Enters Era of Energy ‘Sobriety’
item.description: The government is helping residents with soaring gas and electric costs, but some businesses are already shutting down amid fears of rationing and blackouts.
item.dc:creator: Liz Alderman
item.media:credit: Filip Singer/European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: A Paris street. Some French cities plan to turn off streetlamps to conserve energy in winter.

item.title: Town After Town, Residents Are Fighting Affordable Housing in Connecticut
item.description: Local residents and elected officials are seeking to block large housing projects, warning that increased density could change the character of their towns.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Prevost
item.media:credit: Jane Beiles for The New York Times
item.media:description: Homeowners have raised about $84,000 for a legal fund to fight a proposed apartment complex downtown on Weed Street in New Canaan, Conn.

item.title: Chile Voters Reject New, Left-Leaning Constitution
item.description: The rejected constitution would have legalized abortion, adopted universal health care and enshrined more than 100 constitutional rights, a global record.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.media:description: Celebrating the rejection of the proposed constitution in Santiago, Chile, on Sunday.

item.title: En Chile gana el ‘rechazo’ en el plebiscito por la Constitución
item.description: El texto rechazado habría legalizado el aborto, adoptado la atención médica universal y consagrado más de 100 derechos constitucionales, un récord mundial.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Rodrigo Garrido/Reuters
item.media:description: La votación en Valparaíso, Chile, el domingo. La visión que planteaba la Constitución propuesta resultó ser demasiado drástica como transformación para la mayoría del país.

item.title: The Curious Hole in My Head
item.description: Born without my left temporal lobe, a brain region thought to be critical for language, I’ve been a research subject for much of my life.
item.dc:creator: Helen Santoro
item.media:credit: Kayana Szymczak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Helen Santoro, left, examining a scan of her brain with her mother at an M.I.T. lab in Cambridge, Mass., in July.

item.title: The Final Days of New York’s ‘Wild West’ Outdoor Dining Scene
item.description: The city has removed dozens of dining sheds and is considering more regulations for those that remain.
item.dc:creator: Dodai Stewart and Timothy Mulcare
item.media:credit: Timothy Mulcare for The New York Times

item.title: Review: “The Godmother,” by Barbie Latza Nadeau.
item.description: In Barbie Latza Nadeau’s “The Godmother,” we meet the women who have run the mob, and the new generation poised to take over.
item.dc:creator: Clyde Haberman
item.media:credit: Archive/EPA, via Shutterstock

item.title: Biden Shouldn’t Apologize to Republicans
item.description: The president said that Trumpism resembles “semi-fascism.” He’s right.
item.dc:creator: Charles M. Blow
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times

item.title: The Way You Get Around New York City by Bus and Train Is About to Change
item.description: The city’s crumbling infrastructure is finally getting some upgrades.
item.dc:creator: Mara Gay and Timothy Mulcare

item.title: How Cesar Chavez’s Union Lost Its Way
item.description: Workers have to be persuaded that to join a union is worth the risk.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Pawel
item.media:credit: Patrick T. Fallon/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A statue of Cesar Chavez in San Fernando, Calif.

item.title: Education in America: School Is for Learning to Read
item.description: All kinds of kids, from all kinds of families — rich, poor and middle class — need more help with reading than they’re getting in school.
item.dc:creator: Emily Hanford
item.media:credit: Illustration by Chloe Scheffe; photographs by Internet Archive; Carlton Smith, via Library of Congress; Everyday Basics and Drahomír Posteby-Mach, via Unsplash; Mikus, via Wikimedia Commons; and photos-public-domain.com

item.title: ‘House of the Dragon’ Is Less Sexist and Racist. But Is it Good?
item.description: The showrunners say they’ve heard and responded to criticism of “Game of Thrones,” but some say that has made the new show boring.
item.dc:creator: Jeff Yang

item.title: The Post-Colonoscopy Male Friendship Test
item.description: What the pandemic, parenthood and nomadism took away from my life, I replaced with surprisingly intimate connections with other men.
item.dc:creator: Boris Fishman
item.media:credit: Illustration by Frank Augugliaro. Photographs by Getty Images

item.title: Education in America: School Is for Care
item.description: It can be a safe haven for our most vulnerable children.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Grose
item.media:credit: Illustration by Chloe Scheffe; photographs by Internet Archive; Jordan Rowland and the New York Public Library, via Unsplash; and Mikus, via Wikimedia Commons

item.title: Americans Think Our Democracy Is on the Brink. So Does Biden.
item.description: We examine the president’s speech in Philadelphia with Zolan Kanno-Youngs, a White House reporter.
item.dc:creator: Blake Hounshell and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden laid out his concerns about American democracy with a prime-time address on Thursday in Philadelphia.

item.title: Low-Cook Lifestyle
item.description: When it’s just too hot out, lean into cheesy kimchi noodles, hummus plates and flavorful chicken salads.
item.dc:creator: Krysten Chambrot
item.media:credit: Ryan Liebe for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Simon Andrews.

item.title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
item.description: A sweet and mellow comedy wraps its season, and “Rick and Morty” returns.
item.dc:creator: Alexis Soloski
item.category: Club Cumming Presents a Queer Comedy Extravaganza (TV Program)
item.media:credit: Apple TV+
item.media:description: Esther Smith and Rafe Spall in a scene from the Season 3 finale of “Trying.”

item.title: Introducing ‘The Run-Up,’ a Politics Podcast from The New York Times
item.description: The midterm elections are usually a referendum on the party in power. This year, they’re about so much more.
item.media:credit: Photo illustration: The New York Times; Photo: Samuel Corum for The New York Times

item.title: Transgender Youth Find the Magic of Summer Camp
item.description: Indigo Point was created as an oasis, one that organizers saw as all the more necessary after a barrage of conservative legislation focused on transgender young people.
item.dc:creator: Rick Rojas and Rachel Wisniewski
item.media:credit: Rachel Wisniewski for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bonding over cards at Camp Indigo Point in southern Illinois.

item.title: Nick Kyrgios Upsets No. 1 Daniil Medvedev at the U.S. Open
item.description: Medvedev grew frustrated in a four-set loss that ensured neither singles draws will have a repeat winner this year. Kyrgios will play another Russian, No. 27 Karen Khachanov, in the quarterfinals.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Clarey
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nick Kyrgios of Australia had the support of the crowd at Arthur Ashe Stadium in his match against Daniil Medvedev of Russia on Sunday.

item.title: Vietnam’s Plan for Loudspeaker Broadcasts Meets Resistance
item.description: The city of Hanoi may revive regular loudspeaker broadcasts, which were routine before most people had TVs or internet access. Residents are wary of bringing them back.
item.dc:creator: Chau Doan and Mike Ives
item.media:credit: Linh Pham for The New York Times
item.media:description: Loudspeakers in front of shops in Hanoi, Vietnam, late last month.

item.title: Why Is Pickleball So Popular?
item.description: Everyone and their mother seems to be playing. What’s the draw — and is it really a workout?
item.dc:creator: Juno DeMelo
item.media:credit: Caleb Thal for The New York Times

item.title: What to Know About the New Covid Booster Shots
item.description: New shots targeting the latest version of the Omicron variant will be available soon. When should you get yours? Here’s what experts recommend.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Charity Rachelle for The New York Times
item.media:description: The new shots target the Omicron subvariant BA.5, the dominant version of the virus.

item.title: As Serena Williams Plays Her Final Matches, a Generation Is Inspired
item.description: Women across the country have seen their own lives reflected in the triumphs and trials of the tennis superstar. Cue the swell of emotion.
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times

item.title: Why We Get Motion Sick, and How to Stop It
item.description: Experts say prevention is the best cure.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Illustration by Guillem Casasus; Photograph by Getty Images

item.title: How to Stay Hydrated in a Heat Wave
item.description: Many countries across the globe are facing dangerously high temperatures. Here’s what to do to stay safe.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Seo
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: How an Afghan Soccer Player Escaped the Taliban and Began a New Life
item.description: How an Afghan soccer player and her teammates fled their homes, outran a murderous regime and forged the uncertain beginnings of a new life.
item.dc:creator: Juliet Macur
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar/The New York Times
